div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe center; width: 1px; height: 1px; padding-top: 630px; margin-left: 965px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: center;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: nowrap;

div.div:
Account "Data" (APIs)
exposing Account Control Info & "Account" Data via a standard authorisation model from one "endpoint"
anything exposed via here supports "proxy" use. Other data / services can be on boarded here

display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; overflow-wrap: normal;

div.div:
Exposure?
Level 1 - Relationships - some other service just wants to read a list of relationships, maybe to integrate with own existing authorisation model with data that is not exposed via account
Level 2 - Authorisation / ACL Platform - some other services wants to know who can do what with someone elses data, maybe to integrate with own existing authorisation model with data that is not exposed via account
Level 3 - Exposing Data through API Platform with common Auth - some other platform wants to expose their data via the account API endpoint and using the account authorisation platform
Level 4 - Consuming Data from Account API Platform - some other app / background service wants to read and/or write data that is exposed via account
Notes
User consent required for all apps / services / clients that want to read / write to account data e.g. "NHS App wants to write to your blood pressure - approve/deny".
"Account Control and Authorisation" - Sits in the middle between IdPs and Clients and Data - controlling who can access what data and via what client app, avaliable "as a service" for other data sources to utilise instead of rolling their own authorisation - removing their need to worry about proxy etc
Account is client app platform agnostic. ie. this is not something "in nhs app". This is a platform that app can use, as could other third party apps / website etc in the future.

div.div: 1 to Many - 1 Account may have multiple users

switch.text: 1 to Many - 1 Account may have multiple users

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe center; width: 1px; height: 1px; padding-top: 1035px; margin-left: 340px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: center;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: nowrap;

div.div:
Notes.
Account doesn't "use" NHS number provided by NHS Login as the "context"
The context of account (NHS Number) is stored in account,
supporting proxy/delegate as additional "users" stored in account
"Account" onboards with NHS Login, not every data source that is exposed via it.

div.div: NHS Account - Digital Verifiable Creds Issuer

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe center; width: 292px; height: 1px; padding-top: 1280px; margin-left: 1581px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: center;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; overflow-wrap: normal;

div.div:
Proving the relationships between people
this data is exposed via the standard "Account Data" API
Other services could use this to implement there own proxy/delegation in their own Authorisation layer, but using our list of "trusted relationships".
Account uses this to setup Account User Role mappings - ie when the "target" (delegator) is not involved in the process directly, eg its being updated so that some one can have access to anothers records after they have provided a digital Power of Att. cred

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe center; width: 298px; height: 1px; padding-top: 995px; margin-left: 1581px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: center;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; overflow-wrap: normal;

div.div:
Keeping track of what can do what with what data and how they access it
Can onboard additional services to expose their data using the standard account Authorisation model
Support additional apps / clients to consume data
External services could access the roles / users via the Account APIs etc and implement own authorisation based on it
Citizens can can "self serve" and be empowered to control giving access here, without the need for the proxy service.
Also here they can control and revoke what appications there data can be accesed Via

switch.text: Keeping track of what can do what with what data a...

div.div:
Consuming Data / Functionality via a standard endpoint and standard Authorisation model
Both Citien facing - ie a mobile App or web app.
And.. "Background" Services, ie data analysis etc

div.div:
"Summaries" tying together different data source
eg API blood pressure summary combining GP recorded BPs and user generated BPs

div.div:
Spotting Patterns and information and flagging it.
eg B Background service for analysing blood pressure change over time,
and API exposing a flag that citizen has high blood pressure thats increased over 6 months

div.div:
Additional Notes / Thinking
Anything that is exposed as part of "Account" by defacto has "Proxy" support
Any new / existing services that are onboarded with "Account" in the future, by defacto has "Proxy" support
Anything exposed through Account has support for User controlled consent (and revocation) for both who can access their data, and also via what client application
Support CIS2 for another IdP? Allow users to choose to share with health professionals? Especially around user generated health data?

div.style: display: flex; align-items: unsafe center; justify-content: unsafe center; width: 578px; height: 1px; padding-top: 430px; margin-left: 2671px;
box-sizing: border-box; font-size: 0px; text-align: center;
display: inline-block; font-size: 12px; font-family: Helvetica; color: rgb(0, 0, 0); line-height: 1.2; pointer-events: all; white-space: normal; overflow-wrap: normal;

div.div:
Notes on Different Levels on functionality exposed by account
What account "does" has been very muddled up until now
Separate into 2 sections - account control, and account "data"
Account "Data" can be made clearer by showing different levels of functionality
From the very bottom - data - (the foundation) is exposing existing and new data via a standard authorisation model
Next, Information - taking sections from different exposed data, and creating a "summary" or joined up thinking that provides extra "value"
Knowledge - this is taking data and information, looking for patterns, or analysis - and exposing this found knowledge for others to use
Wisdom - taking knowledge and proactively doing something with it. "Personalising offered services" in an nhs mobile app could be classified as this

switch.text: Notes on Different Levels on functionality exposed by account...
